explain for me these code const buttons = document.querySelectorAll(".btnDropDown"); const opens = document.querySelectorAll(".open"); buttons.forEach((button) => { button.addEventListener("click", function (e) { const target = e.currentTarget; const ele = target.nextElementSibling; opens.forEach((element) => { if (element !== ele) { element.classList.remove("active"); } }); ele.classList.toggle("active"); }); });
1 / 1

Sure! Here's an explanation of the JavaScript code:

  1. const buttons = document.querySelectorAll(".btnDropDown");:

    • This line selects all elements with the class "btnDropDown" and stores them in the buttons constant.
    • These elements represent the buttons in your HTML code.

  2. const opens = document.querySelectorAll(".open");:

    • This line selects all elements with the class "open" and stores them in the opens constant.
    • These elements represent the dropdown content in your HTML code.

  3. buttons.forEach((button) => { ... });:

    • This line iterates over each button element in the buttons collection using the forEach method.
    • It sets up a click event listener for each button.

  4. button.addEventListener("click", function (e) { ... });:

    • This line adds a click event listener to each button.
    • When a button is clicked, the callback function inside it will be executed.

  5. const target = e.currentTarget;:

    • This line assigns the clicked button (the current target of the event) to the target constant.

  6. const ele = target.nextElementSibling;:

    • This line assigns the next sibling of the clicked button (which is the associated dropdown content) to the ele constant.

  7. opens.forEach((element) => { ... });:

    • This line iterates over each dropdown content element in the opens collection using the forEach method.

  8. if (element !== ele) { ... }:

    • This condition checks if the current dropdown content element is not the same as the one associated with the clicked button.

  9. element.classList.remove("active");:

    • This line removes the "active" class from dropdown content elements that are not the currently clicked one.
    • This ensures that only one dropdown content is visible at a time.

  10. ele.classList.toggle("active");:

    • This line toggles the "active" class on the clicked button's associated dropdown content.
    • If the dropdown content is already active, it will be hidden (class removed), and if it's inactive, it will be displayed (class added).

In summary, the JavaScript code sets up event listeners for the buttons. When a button is clicked, it toggles the visibility of the associated dropdown content by adding or removing the "active" class. This allows the user to show or hide the dropdown content as needed.

i want in my funtion it will change character - to span when i click on the button

To change the character "-" to a <span> element when you click the button, you can modify the inner HTML of the <span> element dynamically. Here's an updated version of the code:

javascript
const button = document.querySelector(".btnDropDown");
const span = button.querySelector("span");

button.addEventListener("click", function() {
  if (span.innerHTML === "-") {
    span.innerHTML = "<span>+</span>";
  } else {
    span.innerHTML = "-";
  }
});

In the above code, the addEventListener function is used to listen for a click event on the button. When the button is clicked, the code checks the current inner HTML of the <span> element. If it is "-", it replaces it with <span>+</span>, and vice versa.

Now, whenever you click the button, the character "-" will toggle between being a plain text and being wrapped inside a <span> element.

If you want to toggle the text of the <span> element inside the button between "-" and "+", you can modify the code as follows:

javascript
const buttons = document.querySelectorAll(".btnDropDown");
const opens = document.querySelectorAll(".open");

buttons.forEach((button) => {
  button.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
    const currentButton = e.currentTarget;
    const dropdownContent = currentButton.nextElementSibling;
    const span = currentButton.querySelector("span");

    opens.forEach((element) => {
      if (element !== dropdownContent) {
        element.classList.remove("active");
      }
    });

    if (span.innerText === "-") {
      span.innerText = "+";
    } else {
      span.innerText = "-";
    }

    dropdownContent.classList.toggle("active");
  });
});

In the updated code, after removing the "active" class from other dropdown content elements, it checks the current text of the <span> element. If it is "-", it changes it to "+", and vice versa, before toggling the "active" class on the dropdown content element.

Now, when you click a button, the text inside the <span> element will toggle between "-" and "+".

Here are the steps you can follow to resolve the issue:

  1. First, ensure you have a clean working directory by committing or stashing any pending changes.

  2. Execute the following command to fetch the latest changes from the remote repository:

    sql
    git fetch

    This will update your local repository with the latest commits from the remote branch.

  3. Once the fetch is complete, you can merge the remote changes into your local branch. If you're working on the master branch, for example, you can run the following command:

    bash
    git merge origin/master

    Replace origin/master with the appropriate remote branch name if you're working on a different branch.

    perl
    git push origin <branch-name>

    Replace <branch-name> with the name of your local branch.

By following these steps, you should be able to integrate the remote changes into your local branch and push the updated code to the remote repository.

i have javascript code that when user click on button it will return search result but i want to save the checked in this button
1 / 1

To save the checked state of a button in JavaScript, you can utilize the localStorage API. Here's an example of how you can achieve this:

HTML:

html
<button id="searchButton" type="button">Search</button>

JavaScript:

javascript
// Get the search button element
const searchButton = document.getElementById("searchButton");

// Check if there is a saved checked state in localStorage
const checkedState = localStorage.getItem("searchButtonChecked");

// Set the initial checked state of the button
if (checkedState === "true") {
  searchButton.checked = true;
}

// Add event listener to handle button click
searchButton.addEventListener("click", function() {
  // Perform the search operation here

  // Save the checked state in localStorage
  localStorage.setItem("searchButtonChecked", searchButton.checked);
});

In this code, we first check if there is a saved checked state in localStorage using localStorage.getItem("searchButtonChecked"). If there is a value, we set the initial checked state of the button accordingly.

When the button is clicked, we perform the search operation (you can replace this part with your actual search logic) and then save the checked state of the button using localStorage.setItem("searchButtonChecked", searchButton.checked).

By utilizing localStorage, the checked state of the button will persist even if the user refreshes the page or navigates away and comes back later.

so how can i check this localStorage
1 / 1

To check the value stored in localStorage, you can use the localStorage.getItem() method. Here's an example of how you can retrieve the checked state of the button from localStorage:

javascript
// Get the stored checked state from localStorage
const storedCheckedState = localStorage.getItem("searchButtonChecked");

// Check if there is a stored checked state
if (storedCheckedState) {
  // Convert the stored value to a boolean
  const isChecked = storedCheckedState === "true";

  // Perform any necessary actions based on the stored checked state
  if (isChecked) {
    // The button was previously checked, so you can update the UI accordingly
    console.log("The button was checked.");
  } else {
    // The button was previously unchecked
    console.log("The button was unchecked.");
  }
} else {
  // There is no stored checked state
  console.log("No stored checked state found.");
}

In this code, localStorage.getItem("searchButtonChecked") retrieves the stored value associated with the key "searchButtonChecked". If there is a stored value, it is then converted to a boolean using storedCheckedState === "true". Based on the retrieved checked state, you can perform any necessary actions or update the UI accordingly.

Remember to replace the console.log() statements with your own logic or actions based on the checked state.

Certainly! In a servlet, you can retrieve the values of parameters from the URL using the getParameter() method of the HttpServletRequest object. Here's an example of how you can get the values of "Gender" and "Price" parameters in a servlet:

java
import javax.servlet.ServletException;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse;
import java.io.IOException;

public class MyServlet extends HttpServlet {
    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {
        String gender = request.getParameter("Gender");
        String price = request.getParameter("Price");

        // Use the retrieved parameter values as needed
        System.out.println("Gender: " + gender);
        System.out.println("Price: " + price);

        // Rest of your servlet logic
    }
}

In this example, the doGet() method of the servlet is invoked when a GET request is made to the servlet. Inside the method, request.getParameter("Gender") and request.getParameter("Price") are used to retrieve the values of the "Gender" and "Price" parameters, respectively. You can then use these parameter values as needed in your servlet logic.

Make sure to configure your servlet in the web.xml file or using annotations, and map it to the appropriate URL pattern so that it can handle requests.

To keep the state of the checked options when submitting the form, you can utilize session or request attributes in a servlet or JSP. Here's an example of how you can achieve this using a servlet:

java
import javax.servlet.ServletException;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServlet;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletRequest;
import javax.servlet.http.HttpServletResponse;
import java.io.IOException;

public class MyServlet extends HttpServlet {
    protected void doGet(HttpServletRequest request, HttpServletResponse response) throws ServletException, IOException {
        String gender = request.getParameter("Gender");
        String price = request.getParameter("priceRange");

        // Store the checked options in session or request attributes
        request.getSession().setAttribute("selectedGender", gender);
        request.getSession().setAttribute("selectedPriceRange", price);

        // Redirect back to the same page or to another page
        response.sendRedirect(request.getContextPath() + "/your-form-page.jsp");
    }
}

In this example, the servlet receives the selected values of "Gender" and "priceRange" parameters from the form submission. It then stores these values in session or request attributes using request.getSession().setAttribute() method.

You can access these attributes later in a JSP page to retrieve the selected values and set the corresponding checkboxes as checked. Here's an example of how you can do it in a JSP:

jsp
<form action="your-servlet-url" method="GET">
    <div class="gender">
        <h4>GIỚI TÍNH</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nam" value="male" <% if ("male".equals(request.getSession().getAttribute("selectedGender"))) out.print("checked"); %>>
        <label for="Nam">Nam</label>

        <!-- Other gender radio buttons -->

    </div>
    <div class="price">
        <h4>THEO GIÁ</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="low" value="1500000-3000000" <% if ("1500000-3000000".equals(request.getSession().getAttribute("selectedPriceRange"))) out.print("checked"); %>>
        <label for="low">1.500.000 - 3.000.000</label>

        <!-- Other price radio buttons -->

    </div>
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

In the JSP code, you can use <% if(condition) out.print("checked"); %> to conditionally add the "checked" attribute to the radio button based on the stored attribute values retrieved from the session.

Make sure to replace "your-servlet-url" with the actual URL to your servlet and update the JSP file accordingly with the correct form structure and elements.

Certainly! If you prefer to handle the state persistence and checked options using JavaScript, you can achieve it using the following approach:

html
<form id="myForm">
    <div class="gender">
        <h4>GIỚI TÍNH</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nam" value="male">
        <label for="Nam">Nam</label>

        <!-- Other gender radio buttons -->

    </div>
    <div class="price">
        <h4>THEO GIÁ</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="low" value="1500000-3000000">
        <label for="low">1.500.000 - 3.000.000</label>

        <!-- Other price radio buttons -->

    </div>
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
</form>

javascript
// Retrieve the form element and add a submit event listener
const form = document.getElementById("myForm");
form.addEventListener("submit", function(e) {
    // Prevent the default form submission
    e.preventDefault();

    // Get the selected gender and price range values
    const gender = document.querySelector('input[name="Gender"]:checked').value;
    const price = document.querySelector('input[name="priceRange"]:checked').value;

    // Store the values in localStorage
    localStorage.setItem("selectedGender", gender);
    localStorage.setItem("selectedPriceRange", price);

    // Submit the form programmatically
    form.submit();
});

// Check if there are any stored values in localStorage
const storedGender = localStorage.getItem("selectedGender");
const storedPriceRange = localStorage.getItem("selectedPriceRange");

// Check the corresponding radio buttons if stored values exist
if (storedGender) {
    const genderRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="Gender"][value="${storedGender}"]`);
    genderRadio.checked = true;
}

if (storedPriceRange) {
    const priceRangeRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="priceRange"][value="${storedPriceRange}"]`);
    priceRangeRadio.checked = true;
}

In this JavaScript code, we first retrieve the form element by its ID (myForm) and attach a submit event listener to it. Inside the event listener, we prevent the default form submission behavior using e.preventDefault().

Then, we retrieve the selected gender and price range values from the radio buttons using their name attribute and the :checked selector. We store these values in the localStorage using localStorage.setItem().

Next, we programmatically submit the form using form.submit() to trigger the form submission.

When the page loads, we check if there are any stored values in the localStorage for the selected gender and price range. If stored values exist, we find the corresponding radio buttons and set their checked property to true, thereby marking them as checked.

Please note that this JavaScript code assumes that the form element has an ID of "myForm". You can adjust the code accordingly if you use a different ID or selector for your form.

Apologies for the confusion. If you want to persist the selected options when the form is submitted, you can modify the JavaScript code as follows:

javascript
// Retrieve the form element and add a submit event listener
const form = document.getElementById("searchForm");
form.addEventListener("submit", function(e) {
    // Get the selected gender and price range values
    const gender = document.querySelector('input[name="Gender"]:checked').value;
    const price = document.querySelector('input[name="priceRange"]:checked').value;

    // Append the selected options as query parameters to the form action URL
    const actionUrl = new URL(form.action);
    actionUrl.searchParams.set('Gender', gender);
    actionUrl.searchParams.set('Price', price);
    form.action = actionUrl.href;

    // No need to prevent the default form submission behavior
});

// Check if there are any URL parameters for Gender and Price
const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
const genderParam = urlParams.get('Gender');
const priceParam = urlParams.get('Price');

// Check the corresponding radio buttons if URL parameters exist
if (genderParam) {
    const genderRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="Gender"][value="${genderParam}"]`);
    genderRadio.checked = true;
}

if (priceParam) {
    const priceRangeRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="priceRange"][value="${priceParam}"]`);
    priceRangeRadio.checked = true;
}

In this modified JavaScript code, we retrieve the form element using its ID (searchForm) and attach a submit event listener to it. Inside the event listener, we retrieve the selected gender and price range values as before.

Instead of storing the selected options in localStorage, we now modify the form's action URL to include the selected options as query parameters. We use the URLSearchParams API to handle URL parameters conveniently.

When the page loads, we check if there are any URL parameters for Gender and Price. If parameters exist, we find the corresponding radio buttons and set their checked property to true.

Make sure to replace the existing JavaScript code with this modified code and give it a try.

Apologies for the confusion. If you don't want to modify the URL, you can use JavaScript to persist the selected options without changing the form action.

Here's an updated version of the JavaScript code that stores the selected options in the browser's localStorage:

javascript
// Retrieve the form element
const form = document.getElementById("searchForm");

// Add a change event listener to the form
form.addEventListener("change", function(e) {
    // Get the selected gender and price range values
    const gender = document.querySelector('input[name="Gender"]:checked').value;
    const price = document.querySelector('input[name="priceRange"]:checked').value;

    // Store the selected options in localStorage
    localStorage.setItem("selectedGender", gender);
    localStorage.setItem("selectedPrice", price);
});

// Check if there are any previously selected options in localStorage
const selectedGender = localStorage.getItem("selectedGender");
const selectedPrice = localStorage.getItem("selectedPrice");

// Check the corresponding radio buttons if previously selected options exist
if (selectedGender) {
    const genderRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="Gender"][value="${selectedGender}"]`);
    genderRadio.checked = true;
}

if (selectedPrice) {
    const priceRangeRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="priceRange"][value="${selectedPrice}"]`);
    priceRangeRadio.checked = true;
}

In this updated code, we use the localStorage object to store the selected gender and price range values whenever a change event occurs on the form. The values are stored with the keys "selectedGender" and "selectedPrice".

When the page loads, we check if there are any previously selected options stored in localStorage. If stored values exist, we find the corresponding radio buttons and set their checked property to true.

Please replace the existing JavaScript code with this updated code and test it out. The selected options should be persisted even after form submissions or page refreshes.

To check the valid input radio based on the URL parameters, you can retrieve the URL parameters using JavaScript and then compare them with the radio inputs to set the checked state accordingly. Here's an example:

javascript
// Retrieve the URL parameters
const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
const genderParam = urlParams.get('Gender');
const priceRangeParam = urlParams.get('priceRange');

// Check the corresponding radio buttons if URL parameters match
if (genderParam) {
  const genderRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="Gender"][value="${genderParam}"]`);
  if (genderRadio) {
    genderRadio.checked = true;
  }
}

if (priceRangeParam) {
  const priceRangeRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="priceRange"][value="${priceRangeParam}"]`);
  if (priceRangeRadio) {
    priceRangeRadio.checked = true;
  }
}

In this code, we use the URLSearchParams object to retrieve the URL parameters from the window.location.search. We then compare the parameters with the radio inputs using the value attribute.

Please add this JavaScript code after your form HTML. It will check the URL parameters and set the corresponding radio inputs as checked if the parameters match.

To prevent the page from scrolling to the top when submitting the form or clicking the radio inputs, you can use JavaScript to handle the form submission and prevent the default behavior. Here's an updated version of your form with the necessary JavaScript code:

html
<form action="" id="searchForm" method="GET">
    <div class="gender">
        <h4>GIỚI TÍNH</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nam" value="male">
        <label for="Nam">Nam</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nữ" value="female">
        <label for="Nữ">Nữ</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Unisex" value="unisex">
        <label for="Unisex">Unisex</label>
    </div>
    <div class="price">
        <h4>THEO GIÁ</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="low" value="1500000-3000000">
        <label for="low">1.500.000 - 3.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="medium" value="3000000-5000000">
        <label for="medium">3.000.000 - 5.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="high" value="5000000-100000000">
        <label for="high"> >5.000.000</label>
    </div>
    <input type="submit" value="Search" onclick="submitForm(event)">
</form>

<script>
    function submitForm(event) {
        event.preventDefault(); // Prevent the default form submission behavior
        const form = document.getElementById('searchForm');
        const gender = form.querySelector('input[name="Gender"]:checked');
        const priceRange = form.querySelector('input[name="priceRange"]:checked');

        // Retrieve the selected values
        const genderValue = gender ? gender.value : '';
        const priceRangeValue = priceRange ? priceRange.value : '';

        // Generate the new URL with the selected values
        const newUrl = `Product/List?Gender=${genderValue}&priceRange=${priceRangeValue}`;

        // Redirect to the new URL
        window.location.href = newUrl;
    }
</script>

In this code, we've added an onclick event handler to the submit button. The submitForm function is called when the button is clicked. It prevents the default form submission behavior using event.preventDefault(). Then, it retrieves the selected radio values and generates a new URL based on those values. Finally, it redirects the page to the new URL using window.location.href.

Make sure to replace the action attribute of the form with your desired URL endpoint.

To disable scrolling when submitting the form, you can add an onsubmit event handler to the form and call the preventDefault() method to prevent the default form submission behavior. Here's the modified code:

html
<form action="" id="searchForm" method="GET" onsubmit="event.preventDefault();">
    <div class="gender">
        <h4>GIỚI TÍNH</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nam" value="male" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="Nam">Nam</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nữ" value="female" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="Nữ">Nữ</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Unisex" value="unisex" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="Unisex">Unisex</label>
    </div>
    <div class="price">
        <h4>THEO GIÁ</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="low" value="1500000-3000000" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="low">1.500.000 - 3.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="medium" value="3000000-5000000" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="medium">3.000.000 - 5.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="high" value="5000000-100000000" onchange="this.form.submit()">
        <label for="high"> >5.000.000</label>
    </div>
    <input type="submit" value="Search">
</form>

In this code, the onsubmit attribute is added to the form tag with the value event.preventDefault();. This prevents the default form submission behavior, which includes reloading the page and potentially scrolling to the top. Now, when you submit the form, it won't trigger any scrolling behavior.

Note that if you want to perform some additional actions or handle the form submission using JavaScript, you can modify the onsubmit attribute to call a JavaScript function instead of using event.preventDefault() directly inline.

Apologies for the confusion. If you still want to submit the form without scrolling to the top of the page, you can achieve that using JavaScript. Here's an example:

html
<form action="" id="searchForm" method="GET">
    <div class="gender">
        <h4>GIỚI TÍNH</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nam" value="male">
        <label for="Nam">Nam</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Nữ" value="female">
        <label for="Nữ">Nữ</label>

        <input type="radio" name="Gender" id="Unisex" value="unisex">
        <label for="Unisex">Unisex</label>
    </div>
    <div class="price">
        <h4>THEO GIÁ</h4>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="low" value="1500000-3000000">
        <label for="low">1.500.000 - 3.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="medium" value="3000000-5000000">
        <label for="medium">3.000.000 - 5.000.000</label>
        <br>
        <input type="radio" name="priceRange" id="high" value="5000000-100000000">
        <label for="high"> >5.000.000</label>
    </div>
    <input type="submit" value="Search">
</form>

<script>
    document.getElementById('searchForm').addEventListener('submit', function (e) {
        e.preventDefault(); // Prevent default form submission

        // Get the form data
        const formData = new FormData(this);

        // Construct the URL with the form data
        const url = new URL(window.location.href);
        formData.forEach((value, key) => {
            url.searchParams.set(key, value);
        });

        // Perform your desired action with the constructed URL
        // For example, redirect to the new URL
        window.location.href = url.toString();
    });
</script>

In this code, the submit event of the form is captured using JavaScript. When the form is submitted, the event handler function is called. It prevents the default form submission behavior using e.preventDefault(). Then, it retrieves the form data using FormData and constructs a new URL by setting the form data as search parameters. Finally, you can perform your desired action with the constructed URL, such as redirecting to the new URL.

Make sure to replace // Perform your desired action with the constructed URL with your actual code logic, such as making an AJAX request or performing further processing on the form data.

To achieve this functionality, you can use JavaScript to handle the click event on the anchor tags (a tags) and store the clicked value in localStorage. Additionally, you can use CSS to style the anchor tag with an underline based on whether it has been clicked or not. Here's how you can do it:

HTML (unchanged):

html
<div class="list-brand">
    <ul>
        <% rs = (ResultSet) request.getAttribute("BDResultSet");
            while (rs != null && rs.next()) {%>
        <li>
            <a href="/Product/List/BrandID/<%=rs.getInt("ID")%>">
                <%=rs.getString(2)%>
            </a>
        </li>

        <% }
            rs = null; %>
    </ul>
</div>

JavaScript and CSS:

html
<style>
    .list-brand a.clicked {
        text-decoration: underline;
    }
</style>

<script>
    // Add event listeners to all anchor tags inside the list-brand element
    const anchorTags = document.querySelectorAll(".list-brand a");
    anchorTags.forEach((anchorTag) => {
        anchorTag.addEventListener("click", function (event) {
            event.preventDefault(); // Prevent default link behavior

            // Store the clicked value in localStorage
            const clickedValue = this.getAttribute("href");
            localStorage.setItem("clickedValue", clickedValue);

            // Add the "clicked" class to the clicked anchor tag
            anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
                tag.classList.remove("clicked");
            });
            this.classList.add("clicked");

            // Redirect to the clicked URL (optional)
            window.location.href = clickedValue;
        });
    });

    // Check if there's a previously clicked value in localStorage and add the "clicked" class accordingly
    const storedClickedValue = localStorage.getItem("clickedValue");
    if (storedClickedValue) {
        anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
            if (tag.getAttribute("href") === storedClickedValue) {
                tag.classList.add("clicked");
            }
        });
    }
</script>

In this code, we first add an event listener to each anchor tag inside the .list-brand element. When an anchor tag is clicked, it will prevent the default link behavior using event.preventDefault(), store the clicked value in localStorage, and add the class "clicked" to the clicked anchor tag. The class "clicked" has CSS styling that underlines the anchor tag.

Additionally, when the page loads, we check if there's a previously clicked value stored in localStorage. If there is, we add the "clicked" class to the corresponding anchor tag to maintain the visual representation of the previously clicked anchor tag.

Remember to replace the window.location.href = clickedValue; line with your actual logic if you don't want to redirect the page to the clicked URL.

Certainly! Here's the updated JavaScript code with the additional functionality you requested:

javascript
const storage = document.getElementById("products");
let products = Array.from(storage.getElementsByClassName("product"));
const searchBox = document.getElementById("searchBox");
const selection = document.getElementById("top");
const radioButtons = document.querySelectorAll('input[name="priceRange"]');


const form = document.getElementById("searchForm");

const url = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search);
const gender = url.get("Gender");
const price = url.get("priceRange")

if(gender){
  const genderRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="Gender"][value="${gender}"]`);
  if(genderRadio){
    genderRadio.checked = true;
  }
}

if(price){
  const priceRadio = document.querySelector(`input[name="priceRange"][value="${price}"]`);
  if(priceRadio){
    priceRadio.checked = true;
  }
}

// Function to disable scrolling
function disableScroll() {
  window.onscroll = function() {
    window.scrollTo(0, 0);
  };
}

function enableScroll() {
  window.onscroll = function() {};
}

searchBox.addEventListener("keypress", function(event){
  if(event.key == "Enter"){
    findProduct(searchBox.value);
  }
});

radioButtons.forEach(function (radioButton) {
  radioButton.addEventListener('click', findByPrice);
});


function findProduct(value) {   // find by search box 
  storage.innerHTML = "";
  storage.appendChild(selection);
  products.forEach(function(product){
    const itemName = product.querySelector(".product-name").textContent.toString().toLowerCase();
    const itemBrand = product.querySelector(".product-brand").textContent.toString().toLowerCase();
    if(itemName.includes(value.toLowerCase()) || itemBrand.includes(value.toLowerCase())){
      // product.style.display = "flex";
      storage.appendChild(product);
    }
    else{
      product.style.display = "none";
    }
  });
}

function findByPrice() {   
  const selectedOption = document.querySelector("input[name = priceRange]:checked").value;
  products.forEach(function(product){
    const productPrice = parseFloat(product.querySelector(".product-price").textContent.replace(/\D/g, ''));

    if((selectedOption === "low" && productPrice >= 1500000 && productPrice <= 3000000)
      ||(selectedOption === "medium" && productPrice >= 3000000 && productPrice <= 5000000)
      ||(selectedOption === "high" && productPrice >= 5000000 )
    ){
      product.style.display = "flex";
    }
    else{
      product.style.display = "none";
    }
  })
}

function callSorting(type){
  if(type === "lowToHigh"){
    sortPriceLowToHigh();
  }
  else if(type === "highToLow"){
    sortPriceHighToLow();
  }
  else {
    products.forEach(function (product) {
      product.style.display = "flex";
      storage.appendChild(product);
    });
    
    searchBox.value = "";
    radioButtons.forEach(function (item) {
      item.checked = false;
    });
    sortPriceLowToHigh();
  }
}

function sortPriceLowToHigh() {
  products.sort(function(a, b){
    var priceA = parseFloat(a.querySelector('.product-price').textContent.replace(/\D/g, ''));
    var priceB = parseFloat(b.querySelector('.product-price').textContent.replace(/\D/g, ''));
    return priceA - priceB;
  });

  storage.innerHTML = "";
  storage.appendChild(selection);
  products.forEach(function(product){
    storage.appendChild(product);
  });
}

function sortPriceHighToLow() {
  products.sort(function(a, b){
    var priceA = parseFloat(a.querySelector('.product-price').textContent.replace(/\D/g, ''));
    var priceB = parseFloat(b.querySelector('.product-price').textContent.replace(/\D/g, ''));
    return priceB - priceA;
  });

  storage.innerHTML = "";
  storage.appendChild(selection);
  products.forEach(function(product){
    storage.appendChild(product);
  });
}

// Add event listener to anchor tags inside the "list-brand" element
const anchorTags = document.querySelectorAll(".list-brand a");
anchorTags.forEach((anchorTag) => {
  anchorTag.addEventListener("click", function(event) {
    event.preventDefault(); // Prevent default link behavior

    // Add the "clicked" class to the clicked anchor tag
    anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
      tag.classList.remove("clicked");
    });
    this.classList.add("clicked");

    // Store the clicked value in localStorage
    localStorage.setItem("clickedValue", this.getAttribute("href"));
  });
});

// Check if there's a previously clicked value in localStorage and add the "clicked" class accordingly
const storedClickedValue = localStorage.getItem("clickedValue");
if (storedClickedValue) {
  anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
    if (tag.getAttribute("href") === storedClickedValue) {
      tag.classList.add("clicked");
    }
  });
}

// Enable scrolling after all the modifications
enableScroll();

This updated code includes the addition of the disableScroll and enableScroll functions to disable and enable scrolling when needed. It also adds event listeners to the anchor tags inside the "list-brand" element to store the clicked value in localStorage and apply the "clicked" class to the clicked anchor tag.

Please make sure to place this updated code after the HTML section in your file.

in my git folder i have src and target folder. how can i add git ignore for this target folder
1 / 1

To add a .gitignore file specifically for the target folder in your Git repository, you can follow these steps:

  1. Create a file named .gitignore in the root directory of your Git repository (if it doesn't exist already).

  2. Open the .gitignore file in a text editor.

  3. Add the following line to the file:

    target/

    This line specifies that the target folder and its contents should be ignored by Git.

  4. Save the .gitignore file.

After adding the .gitignore file with the target/ entry, Git will ignore the target folder and its contents when tracking changes. Make sure to commit and push the .gitignore file to your repository so that other collaborators also ignore the target folder.

how can i show file gig ignore in finder macos
1 / 1

By default, macOS hides files and folders with names starting with a dot (e.g., .gitignore). However, you can still show hidden files in Finder on macOS by following these steps:

  1. Open a new Finder window.

  2. Press the keyboard shortcut Command + Shift + Period (.). This shortcut toggles the visibility of hidden files in Finder.

  3. The hidden files, including the .gitignore file, should now be visible in the Finder window.

You can repeat the same keyboard shortcut (Command + Shift + Period) to hide the hidden files again.

Please note that modifying or deleting hidden files can have consequences on your system, so exercise caution when working with them.

1 / 1

To scroll the <ul> element to the right place when a tag with the "clicked" class is clicked, you can use the scrollIntoView() method. Here's an updated version of your code that includes scrolling:

javascript
const anchorTags = document.querySelectorAll(".list-brand a");
const ulElement = document.querySelector(".list-brand ul");

anchorTags.forEach((anchorTag) => {
  anchorTag.addEventListener("click", function(event) {
    anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
      tag.classList.remove("clicked");
    });
    this.classList.add("clicked");
    localStorage.setItem("clickedValue", this.getAttribute("href"));

    // Scroll to the clicked element
    this.scrollIntoView({ behavior: "smooth", block: "nearest", inline: "start" });
  });
});

const storedClickedValue = localStorage.getItem("clickedValue");
if (storedClickedValue) {
  anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
    if (tag.getAttribute("href") === storedClickedValue) {
      tag.classList.add("clicked");

      // Scroll to the clicked element
      tag.scrollIntoView({ behavior: "smooth", block: "nearest", inline: "start" });
    }
  });
}

In the above code, the scrollIntoView() method is called on the clicked element (this) and the element with the "clicked" class (tag). The options { behavior: "smooth", block: "nearest", inline: "start" } ensure smooth scrolling behavior and scroll to the nearest edge of the container. Adjust the options as per your desired scrolling behavior.

Note: Make sure to add the necessary CSS styles to the .clicked class to indicate the clicked state as desired.

To scroll the <ul> element to the right place, with an offset of 50 pixels, when a tag with the "clicked" class is clicked, you can modify the scrollIntoView() options. Here's an updated version of the code that includes the desired offset:

javascript
const anchorTags = document.querySelectorAll(".list-brand a");
const ulElement = document.querySelector(".list-brand ul");

anchorTags.forEach((anchorTag) => {
  anchorTag.addEventListener("click", function(event) {
    anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
      tag.classList.remove("clicked");
    });
    this.classList.add("clicked");
    localStorage.setItem("clickedValue", this.getAttribute("href"));

    // Scroll to the clicked element with an offset of 50 pixels
    this.scrollIntoView({ behavior: "smooth", block: "nearest", inline: "start", offsetTop: -50 });
  });
});

const storedClickedValue = localStorage.getItem("clickedValue");
if (storedClickedValue) {
  anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
    if (tag.getAttribute("href") === storedClickedValue) {
      tag.classList.add("clicked");

      // Scroll to the clicked element with an offset of 50 pixels
      tag.scrollIntoView({ behavior: "smooth", block: "nearest", inline: "start", offsetTop: -50 });
    }
  });
}

In the updated code, the offsetTop option is set to -50 pixels. This will scroll the element to the clicked position minus 50 pixels in the vertical direction. Adjust the offset value as per your requirements.

Remember to apply appropriate CSS styles to ensure that the scrolled position looks visually appealing and aligned with your design.

I apologize for the confusion. It seems there was a misunderstanding in my previous response. To achieve the desired scrolling effect with an offset, you'll need to update the scrolling target element.

Please replace the following line in the code:

javascript
const ulElement = document.querySelector(".list-brand ul");

with:

javascript
const ulElement = document.querySelector(".list-brand");

By selecting the .list-brand element instead of the <ul> element, the scrolling will be applied to the container rather than the individual <li> items.

Here's the updated code with the correction:

javascript
const anchorTags = document.querySelectorAll(".list-brand a");
const ulElement = document.querySelector(".list-brand");

anchorTags.forEach((anchorTag) => {
  anchorTag.addEventListener("click", function(event) {
    anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
      tag.classList.remove("clicked");
    });
    this.classList.add("clicked");
    localStorage.setItem("clickedValue", this.getAttribute("href"));

    // Scroll to the clicked element with an offset of 50 pixels
    ulElement.scrollTo({
      top: this.offsetTop - 50,
      behavior: "smooth"
    });
  });
});

const storedClickedValue = localStorage.getItem("clickedValue");
if (storedClickedValue) {
  anchorTags.forEach((tag) => {
    if (tag.getAttribute("href") === storedClickedValue) {
      tag.classList.add("clicked");

      // Scroll to the clicked element with an offset of 50 pixels
      ulElement.scrollTo({
        top: tag.offsetTop - 50,
        behavior: "smooth"
      });
    }
  });
}

Make sure to replace the previous code block with this updated one. Now, when a tag with the "clicked" class is clicked, the .list-brand element will scroll to the appropriate position with an offset of 50 pixels.

Yes, you can use the text-decoration property along with the text-decoration-line and text-decoration-color properties to achieve an underline effect and customize its appearance, including adding margins.

Here's an example CSS code snippet:

css
.list-brand a {
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-decoration-line: underline;  /* Specifies the type of line, in this case, underline */
  text-decoration-color: blue;  /* Specifies the color of the underline */
  text-decoration-thickness: 2px;  /* Specifies the thickness of the underline */
  margin-bottom: 5px;  /* Adds a margin below the underline */
}

In this example, the text-decoration property is set to "underline" to apply the underline effect. The text-decoration-line property is set to "underline" to ensure it's rendered as an underline. The text-decoration-color property is set to "blue" to define the color of the underline. You can adjust the color value as needed. Additionally, the text-decoration-thickness property is set to "2px" to define the thickness of the underline, and the margin-bottom property is used to add a margin below the underline.

Feel free to adjust the values to meet your specific design requirements.

css
body::-webkit-scrollbar {
  width: 7px;
}

body::-webkit-scrollbar-track {
  background: #f1f1f1;
}

body::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb {
  background: #888;
}

body::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover {
  background: #555;

In this code, the ::-webkit-scrollbar selector targets the scrollbar on the body element. You can adjust the selector to target a different element if needed. The ::-webkit-scrollbar-track selector customizes the background color of the scrollbar's track. The ::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb selector customizes the color of the scrollbar's thumb (the draggable portion). The ::-webkit-scrollbar-thumb:hover selector changes the thumb's color when hovered over.

Feel free to modify the styles and colors to match your design preferences.

1 / 1

To create an animation when scrolling through the image, you can use CSS animations and JavaScript. Here's an example of how you can achieve this effect:

HTML:

html
<div class="row no-gutters">
  <div class="theme">
    <img src="/RESOURCES/images/icons/perfumeStore.jpg" class="scroll-animation">
  </div>
</div>

CSS:

css
.theme {
  width: 100%;
  height: 30%;
  margin-bottom: 50px;
  padding: 0;
  perspective: 10px;
}

.theme img {
  object-fit: cover;
  width: 100%;
  height: 700px;
  perspective: 10px;
  transform: translateZ(-10px) scale(2);
}

@keyframes fade-in {
  from {
    opacity: 0;
    transform: translateZ(-10px) scale(2);
  }
  to {
    opacity: 1;
    transform: translateZ(0) scale(1);
  }
}

JavaScript:

javascript
function scrollAnimation() {
  const images = document.querySelectorAll('.scroll-animation');

  function checkScroll() {
    images.forEach((image) => {
      const position = image.getBoundingClientRect().top;
      const windowHeight = window.innerHeight;

      if (position < windowHeight * 0.8) {
        image.classList.add('animate');
      }
    });
  }

  window.addEventListener('scroll', checkScroll);
  checkScroll();
}

scrollAnimation();

In this example, we add the scroll-animation class to the image element. The CSS animation is defined using @keyframes fade-in with a fade-in effect. The JavaScript code checks the scroll position of each image and adds the animate class when the image is within 80% of the viewport height.

You can customize the animation effect and adjust the scroll position threshold as needed to achieve the desired result.

If you want to create a "parallax" effect where the image appears to pause or slow down as you scroll through it, you can achieve it using CSS and JavaScript. Here's an example implementation:

HTML:

html
<div class="row no-gutters">
  <div class="theme">
    <div class="image-container">
      <img src="/RESOURCES/images/icons/perfumeStore.jpg" class="parallax-image">
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

CSS:

css
.theme {
  width: 100%;
  height: 30%;
  margin-bottom: 50px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.image-container {
  position: relative;
  height: 100%;
}

.parallax-image {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: auto;
  transform: translateZ(0) scale(1.2);
  transition: transform 0.2s ease-out;
}

.parallax-image.stopped {
  transform: translateZ(0) scale(1);
}

JavaScript:

javascript
function parallaxScroll() {
  const images = document.querySelectorAll('.parallax-image');

  function checkScroll() {
    const scrollPosition = window.pageYOffset;
    const windowHeight = window.innerHeight;

    images.forEach((image) => {
      const imagePosition = image.getBoundingClientRect().top;

      if (imagePosition < windowHeight * 0.8) {
        image.classList.add('stopped');
      } else {
        image.classList.remove('stopped');
      }
    });
  }

  window.addEventListener('scroll', checkScroll);
  checkScroll();
}

parallaxScroll();

In this example, we add the parallax-image class to the image element. The CSS applies a scaling transformation to create the initial parallax effect. The JavaScript code checks the scroll position and adds or removes the stopped class based on the image's position relative to the viewport. The stopped class removes the scaling transformation, giving the appearance of the image pausing or slowing down as you scroll through it.

Feel free to adjust the CSS properties and JavaScript logic to fine-tune the parallax effect according to your requirements.

1 / 1
is there any way to do parallax with this without js
1 / 1

Yes, you can achieve a simple parallax effect using only CSS. Here's an example implementation:

HTML:

html
<div class="row no-gutters">
  <div class="theme">
    <div class="image-container">
      <img src="/RESOURCES/images/icons/perfumeStore.jpg" class="parallax-image">
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

CSS:

css
.theme {
  width: 100%;
  height: 30%;
  margin-bottom: 50px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.image-container {
  height: 100%;
  perspective: 1px;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.parallax-image {
  position: relative;
  top: 0;
  left: 0;
  width: 100%;
  height: auto;
  transform: translateZ(-1px) scale(1.2);
  transition: transform 0.2s ease-out;
}

.image-container:hover .parallax-image {
  transform: translateZ(0) scale(1);
}

In this example, we use the hover pseudo-class to trigger the parallax effect when hovering over the image. The CSS transform property is used to apply the scaling and perspective effects, creating the parallax illusion.

Note that this CSS-only solution relies on the hover state, so the parallax effect will only be active when the user hovers over the image. If you need the effect to be active during scrolling, JavaScript is required to detect the scroll position and apply the necessary styles dynamically.
